questions.question: Two bones in the human skull, when joined together at a fibrous joint, form the sides and the roof of the cranium.
Two bones in the human skull, which are roughly quadrilateral in form, has two surfaces, four borders, and four angles.
This bone is named from the latin word for wall
An unpaired bone in the skull that separates the nasal cavity from the brain.
This bone is located at the roof of the nose, between two orbits.
This cubical bone is lightweight due to a spongy construction.
An unpaired bone of the neurocranium situated in the middle of the skull towards the front.
This bone is in front of the temporal bone and the basilar part of the occiptal bone.
This bone's shape somewhat resembles that of a butterfly or bat with its wings extended.
These bones are sitated at the sides and base of the skull, and lateral to the temporal lobes of the cerebral cortex.
These bones are overlaid by the sides of the head known as the temples and house the structures of the ears.
The lower seven cranial nerves and the major vessels to and from the brain traverse this bone.
This bone is a cranial dermal bone, and is the main bone of the occiput (back and lower part of the skull).
This bone is trapezoidal in shape and curved on itself like a shallow dish.
This bone overlies the occipital lobes of the cerebum.
At the base of the skull, in this bone, there is a large oval opening called the framen magnum, which allows the passage of the spinal cord.
This bone contains three portions, the squamous part, the orbital part, and the nasal part.
This bone makes up the bony part of the forehead, part of the bony orbital cavity holding the eye, and part of the bony part of the nose.
This bone comes from the latin word for forehead.
